section.title: History
section.para: XIMS is a flexible web based content management and information system, built to especially suit the needs of academic and educational infrastructures. The XIMS project initially started out as a side project of the reorganization and redesign of the website of the University of Innsbruck, to create a small and simple content management system to manage the University's public web pages. Inspired by an existing information system that was created and used by the Department of Computing Services and an evaluation of the needs of the University of Innsbruck, that intent of pure web content management shifted to the creation of a more generic content management system, which also should be used as an information and communication system.

section.title: Linking Containers
section.para: For linking containers use a trailing slash in the URL to avoid redirects. If you want to link to a possibly existing directory index, do not include a reference to the index itself, for example index.html in the URL

listitem.para: Wrong: /zid/services
Wrong /zid/services/index.html
Correct: /zid/services/

section.title: Relative or absolute links?
section.para: For choosig the format of the URL to use for linking XIMS objects consider the following two different cases:

listitem.para: The parent of the referenced object is the same or a child of the referencing object.
The referenced object is in a different branch of the hierarchy tree.

section.para: For case (1) use links relative to the referencing object. For example let us say the object /somesite/somedepartment/staff.html wants to link to the object /somesite/somedepartment/manuals/rtfm.html . Here, the href-attribute (i.e. the link URI) should say manuals/rtfm.html.

For case (2) use links relative to the root of the current site the object is located in. For example let us say the object /somesite/somedepartment/cooperations.html wants to link to the object /somesite/someotherdepartment/index.html . In that case the link URI should say /someotherdepartment/.
Note: Using the optional WYSIWYG-Editor's link adding facility, the link URLs are generated in the correct way.

abstract.para: The following will provide brief descriptions of the fields you will encounter in XIMS.

section.para: Roughly spoken, the location is the filename for your object. Once it gets published, expect it to show up in the URL for your Object, so choose a telling and rememberable name for it.
However, depending on wich kind of object you are working on, XIMS handles the location a bit differently.
Giving a location is always mandatory.

section.title: Location for document-like objects

listitem.para: XHTML -documents
simple DocBook- XML
XSL -Stylesheets

section.para: The suffix will be automatically added according to the type of object you are working on.

example.title: Example:
example.para: If you are in folder /xims/foo/ , give your brand new XHTML -document a location ' bar ' to get /xims/foo/bar.html .

section.title: Location for file and image objects
section.para: In case you are uploading/changing a file, the name of your file will be the location , so there is no extra ' Location ' field. Instead you will see an upload-widget in the dialog, which allows you to choose a file from your local filesystem. XIMS trusts your browser to send the correct mime-type. The filename will be used unmodified as the location .

section.title: Location for URLLink objects
section.para: URLLinks are different kind of animal: they don't get published; Since they serve for the internal view of XIMS only, again the location behaves a bit differently: It is the target . Any valid URL is valid, be it local or external.

section.title: Title
section.para: Give a 'title' (displayname) for your object
The title will be displayed in:

listitem.para: the list of folder children while browsing folders
the HTML -document-title your browser presents

section.para: Appears in document-related input masks only - and contains their actual 'content'.

section.title: Body in XHTML - Documents
section.para: Depending on your platform, you will get one of two possible views: (in the future, this will be a user-preference too)

listitem.para: Using MSIE and Netscape >= 4.x on Windows, the body is editable with a WYSIWYG-editor, which is described here (german translation).

Using other browsers on other platforms, you're currently tied to using a plain textfield for content input. You are expected to enter your content as well-formed XHTML (strict) ! That means, that you have to convert your existing HTML -files into XHTML (strict). If you are typing or pasting non-wellformed HTML-content, xims uses
tidy to "form" your your input "well", which should be succesful in most cases. In case you recieve a failure notice, you will have to "form" your content "well" manually.

section.title: Body in simpleDocBook-XML Articles
section.para: Same as above, but you can't use the WYSYWIG editor in either case. You might want to write your article in an external editor, like xmlmind.com's XXE for example, and paste it in.
Note that:

listitem.para: Your article must be in wellformed XML .
You have to omit the declarations and PI 's. Required are the document-node's start and ending tags -- and everything between them of course :)

title.literal: Grant VIEW privilege to users of your default roles

section.para: Per default, all users from the roles that are marked as your 'default roles' will have the privilege to view your object after creation. You always have the possibility to modify your object and the privileges granted to others. If you want no one else to view your object, you can avoid that right away from the start by setting this option to "No"
To learn more about users, roles and grants, click here .

section.title: Create autoindex for this container during publishing
section.para: XIMS is able to generate a simple indexdocument for you. (That practically means: if the public webserver gets a request for the folder you published, it will serve a short summary of the published objects in this folder)

This index is generated during the publishing-process of the container. So be aware that adding or removing objects from the public system requires not only the publishing/unpublishing of the objects in question, but also repuplishing of the container to regenerate the index.
This option is currently presented on folder creation and folder editing and defaults to yes.

section.title: Mark object as new
section.para: Sets a flag to mark Objects as new to emphase changes made. If set, a NEW! icon is shown in the folderlistings. The N:xx search command lists objects flagged as new only.

section.title: Publish / Republish / Unpublish
section.para: Publishing-mechanisms will be changed soon! With it, this section!
Per default, your objects solely exist in the xims' database. (The filesystem-like view presented to you is only virtual.)
If you "(Re)Publish" an object it will copied to the web server's filesystem for public delivery.

section.title: Search Field
section.para: The Search field takes search queries and some special short commands.
Constraints:

listitem.para: A query can have up to 55 characters.
Results are limited to the 30 best matches.

section.title: Keyword Search
section.para: Give one or more keywords. If you enter more than one word, the search will be ANDed - returning documents containing both of the words you gave.
Valid operators at the time are:

listitem.para: AND
OR

section.para: This way one can issue more complex queries like: "foo AND ( bar OR b0rk )".

section.title: M:<days>
section.para: Returns objects that have been modyfied in the last <days>.
If the Number of days is ommited, 1 is assumed.

section.title: m:<days>
section.para: Returns objects marked new that have been modyfied in the last <days>.
If the Number of days is ommited, 1 is assumed.

section.title: N:<days>
section.para: Lookup objects by creation time.
If the Number of days is ommited, 1 is assumed.

section.title: n:<days>
section.para: Lookup objects marked new by creation time.
If the Number of days is ommited, 1 is assumed.

section.title: I:[DocumentID]
section.para: Lookup objects per Document ID.

section.title: i:[ID]
section.para: Lookup objects per ID.

section.title: !U:[ID | /path/to/object]
section.para: Unlock objects; The ID or the object's path must be given.

section.title: Basic Privileges
section.para: Filesystem-like Privileges:

listitem.para: View
A user or role may view the object.
Write
A user or role may write into the object, i.e. change its location, content, title or other metadata.
Create
A user or Role has the right to create a new object in this container.
Delete
A user or Role has the right to delete the object from the xims database.
Move
A user or Role has the right to move the object into another container.

section.para: Right to publish

listitem.para: Publish
A user or role has the right to publish, republish and unpublish the object

section.title: Grant Rights
section.para: give the right to grant privileges on this object

listitem.para: Grant
A User or role has the right to grant another user or role rights on this object.

appendix.title: A mini-glossary
appendix.para: site - In XIMS installations first level containers (where the parent is the root folder / ) are referred to as site . For example the object with the path /uniweb/zid/index.html would be located in the site uniweb .
ID - ID of the language-dependend part of the XIMS object. This ID can be seen in the URL while editing objects for example.
Document ID - ID of the language-independend part of the XIMS object.
